Louis G. Redstone Photograph Collection, 1935-2005

Finding aid created by
Amanda Carvell, 2005

did.abstract: Louis Redstone worked as an architect in the Detroit area from the 1930's through 1980's. His buildings include the Micheal Berry International Air Terminal at the Detroit Metropolitan Airport, Manufacturers Bank Operation's Center, Congregation Beth Achim, and the business administration building at Lawrence Technological University. The collection includes photographs of Redstone projects, as well as sketches, floor plans, and blueprints. His interest in art and travel is also well documented through photographs, speeches, writings, and newspaper clippings, as well as his original artwork.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: This collection was donated by Daniel and Barbara Redstone (Donor no. 9542) in December 2004. An addition to the collection was donated by Daniel and Eliel Redstone in March 2005.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has not been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Louis G. Redstone Photograph Collection, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Louis Redstone was born in Grodno, Russia in 1903. In 1920, he went to Palestine as a Pioneer, working to rebuild a Jewish homeland. After three years, he emigrated to Detroit where he worked as a bricklayer. Redstone enrolled in the University of Michigan College of Architecture in 1925, graduating in 1929 with a bachelor's degree. Unable to find work as an architect, he worked as an artist and sculptor. In 1933, Redstone returned to Tel Aviv, where he worked as an architect, later helping to design the Palestine Pavilion for the 1937 World's Fair in Paris. Shortly thereafter, he left Tel Aviv for Detroit, where he started his own architectural firm. His firm specialized in architecture, engineering, interior design, and urban planning. His buildings include the Michael Berry International Air Terminal at the Detroit Metropolitan Airport, Manufacturers Bank Operations Center, Jewish Community Center, Congregation Beth Achim, and the business administration building at Lawrence Technological University.

Even as a practicing architect, Redstone indulged his interest in art, attending the Center for Creative Studies, and the Oxbow School of Art. In the 1940's, Redstone received a master's degree in urban design from the Cranbrook Academy of Art, studying with Eliel Saarinen. In 1978, Redstone was awarded the Gold Medal of the Michigan Society of Architects, the organization's highest honor. The next year, he was elected as an Honorary Fellow of the Royal Academy of Fine Arts at the Hague.
Louis Redstone died in Detroit in 2002, at the age of 99.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of 5 series, Art, Clippings/Publicity, Speeches and Writings, Travel, and Architectural Photographs.

The Art (0.2 linear ft.) series consists of materials relating to Redstone's intense interest in Art. This series includes information on his exhibitions and activities to promote art in the community. Also included is a watercolor painting that was part of an exhibition at the Detroit Institute of Arts.

did.unittitle: Submissions for book on Public Art 1978

scopecontent.p: The Clippings/Publicity (0.3 linear ft.) series consists of newspaper articles by and about Redstone, his career, and public activities. Of note is a scrapbook of photographs and clippings documenting in part his career in Palestine.

did.unittitle: Scrapbook including in part photographs of Palestine buildings and building construction, 1936-1948

odd.p: (include loose clippings dating up to the mid-1950s)

scopecontent.p: The Speeches and Writings (0.3 linear ft.) series contains materials related to Redstone's published books, speaking engagements, and writings for the Michigan Society of Architects.

did.unittitle: Writings on Art in Architecture and Public Art
Michigan Society of Architects Monthly Bulletin March 1959

scopecontent.p: The Travel (0.2 linear ft.) contains documents and photographs relating to Mr. Redstone's travels around the world, for both personal and professional reasons.

The Architectural Photographs (5 linear ft.) series is grouped into 5 subseries. The first subseries, Numbered Jobs, is arranged by project number, which is based on the date the project was commissioned. This subseries comprises the bulk of the collection and includes interior and exterior photographs of Redstone Associates projects, as well as sketches, floor plans, blueprints, and constructions photos. A photocopy of the Redstone Project Log Book is included at the beginning of the subseries. Many of the photographs were taken by Balthazar Korab. The Untitled Jobs are labeled with a negative number, which is based on the project number and the number of the photograph within that project. There is no title or date. This group of photos consists of mostly negatives and some prints of buildings and drawings by Redstone The "K" subseries includes prints and negatives of buildings and drawings done by Redstone. These are not titled or dated, but are labeled with a project number beginning with the letter "K". The "K" and Untitled subseries are not further described. The fourth subseries consists of photographs of Redstone jobs that are labeled with a title, but no job number or date. These are arranged alphabetically by title or category. The fifth subseries contains photographs of buildings and artwork that interested Redstone personally.
